lessons.title: Engine Structures
lessons.content: Engine structure is one of the most fundamental aspects of automotive engineering, defining both performance characteristics and the distinct sound profile of a vehicle. The main types we will discuss here are Inline, V, and Flat. The number after the engine type indicates the number of cylinders in the engine, so a V8 has 8 cylinders.

points.title: Compact
points.description: Inline engines are easier and cheaper to manufacture and maintain with their components aligned in one row. These engines also fit well in compact cars

points.title: Naturally Balanced
points.description: Inline-6 engines are naturally balanced and run very smoothly.

points.title: Handling
points.description: They are lighter and more fuel-efficent due to having fewer moving parts.

points.title: Compact
points.description: V engines have a shorter length than inline engines, so they fit in more vehicles, like those with limited engine bay space

points.title: Naturally Balanced
points.description: V8’s and V12’s are are naturally balanced by overlapping power strokes and symmetrical design, reducing vibrations

points.title: Handling
points.description: The engine sits lower in the vehicle, improving center of gravity and handling

lessons.title: How a Cat-Back Exhaust Affects Sound
lessons.content: A cat-back exhaust system refers to the portion of the exhaust system from the catalytic converter to the exhaust tips. It plays a crucial role in determining your car's sound profile.

points.title: Louder Volume
points.description: Aftermarket cat-back systems often use larger diameter pipes and less restrictive mufflers/resonators, allowing exhaust gases to flow more freely. This results in a louder, more pronounced exhaust note compared to stock systems.

points.title: Deeper or Sharper Tone
points.description: Cat-back systems with resonators produce a smoother, deeper tone, while those without resonators sound sharper and raspier.

points.title: More Aggressive Character
points.description: Many performance cat-back systems are tuned to emphasize a sporty or race-inspired sound, with more crackles, pops, or backfires depending on the car and setup.

points.title: Active Exhaust Valves
points.description: Some cat-back systems feature active exhaust valves that let drivers switch between quiet and aggressive sound modes, offering both comfort and performance at the push of a button or automatically based on driving conditions.

lessons.title: The Catalytic Converter and its Impact on Engine Sound
lessons.content: The number of cells in the catalytic converter has a significant impact on the exhaust sound.

points.title: What is cell count?
points.description: The number of cells per square inch (CPSI) used in the catalytic directly affects airflow and exhaust sound characteristics. Cells are used for filtering exhaust gases.

points.title: High cell count (e.g., 800 CPSI)
points.description: The honeycomb structure is denser, which restricts airflow more. This results in quieter, more subdued exhaust sound—ideal for factory settings and better emissions control.

points.title: Low cell count (e.g., 200 CPSI or catless)
points.description: The structure is more open or removed entirely, allowing gases to flow more freely. This produces a louder, more aggressive, and metallic exhaust note.
